awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: IA: Collaborative Research: Intelligent Solutions for Navigating Big Data from the Arctic and Antarctic
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this research is to investigate artificial intelligence (AI) solutions for data collected by the Center for Remote Sensing of Ice Sheets (CReSIS) in order to provide an intelligent data understanding to automatically mine and analyze the heterogeneous dataset collected by CReSIS. Significant resources have been and will be spent in collecting and storing large and heterogeneous datasets from expensive Arctic and Antarctic fieldwork (e.g. through NSF Big Idea: Navigating the New Arctic). While traditional analyses provide some insight, the complexity, scale, and multidisciplinary nature of the data necessitate advanced intelligent solutions. This project will allow domain scientists to automatically answer questions about the properties of the data, including ice thickness, ice surface, ice bottom, internal layers, ice thickness prediction, and bedrock visualization. The planned approach will advance the broader big data research community by improving the efficiency of deep learning methods and in the investigation of methods to merge data-driven AI approaches with application-specific domain knowledge. Special attention will be given to women and minority involvement in the research and the project will develop new course materials for several classes in AI at a Hispanic and minority serving institute.

In polar radar sounder imagery, the delineation of the ice top and ice bottom and layering within the ice is essential for monitoring and modeling the growth of ice sheets and sea ice. The optimal approach to this problem should merge the radar sounder data with physical ice models and related datasets such as ice coverage and concentration maps, spatiotemporal meteorological maps, and ice velocity. Rather than directly engineering specific relations into the image analysis that require many parameters to be defined and tuned, data-dependent approaches let the machine learn these relationships. To devise intelligent solutions for navigating the big data from the Arctic and Antarctic and to scale up the current and traditional techniques to big data, this project plans several approaches for detecting ice surface, bottom, internal layers, 3D modeling of bedrock and spatial-temporal monitoring of the ice surface: 1) Devise new methodologies based on hybrid networks combining machine learning with traditional domain specific knowledge and transforming the entire deep learning network to the time-frequency domain. 2) Equip the machine with information that is not visible to the human eye or that is hard for a human operator to consider simultaneously, to be able to detect internal layers and 3D basal topography on a large scale. Using the results of the feature tracking of the ice surface in radar altimetry, the research effort will also develop new data-dependent techniques for predicting the ice thickness for following years based on deep recurrent neural networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-funded project ( IIS-2308649, IIS-1838230, IIS-1947584, IIS-1838236) aimed to develop innovative machine learning and computational methods for analyzing radar data from ice sheets, contributing to our understanding of glacial dynamics and climate change. The project focused on developing novel machine learning techniques and creating automated tools to analyze vast datasets collected by the Center for Remote Sensing of Ice Sheets (CReSIS). Through machine learning and advanced modeling, the research team sought to address critical challenges in data analysis and improve predictive capabilities for ice behavior.

Intellectual Merit
The project achieved significant advancements in the automated detection and analysis of ice sheets and sea ice in Greenland and Antarctica. Key accomplishments included:

1.     Physics-Informed Machine Learning for Ice Thickness Prediction 

  • Combined the physics of radar signals with deep learning models, leveraging spatial-frequency domain analyses and wavelet transforms. This hybrid approach significantly improved noise reduction, layer detection, and thickness estimation in radar echograms.
  • Incorporated atmospheric models and domain knowledge into neural networks, enhancing their ability to generalize across regions and datasets. This methodology was validated against physical simulations and field measurements, achieving high levels of precision.

2.     Generative Models for Tracking the Internal Layers of Ice Sheets 

  • Created generative models to synthesize realistic radar images for data augmentation, improving layer-tracking algorithm performance when combined with real data.
  • Published findings demonstrating that while GAN-augmented models perform better, synthetic data alone cannot fully replicate radar characteristics like noise and Doppler effects.

3.     Graph Neural Networks for Spatiotemporal Prediction 

  • Developed spatial-temporal machine learning models using Graph Convolutional Networks and Recurrent Neural Networks to predict annual snow accumulation trends in Greenland.
  • Demonstrated that graph-based methods effectively capture relationships between ice layers, delivering robust predictions for shallow and deep ice thickness.

4.     Sea Ice Monitoring and Analysis

  • Expanded research efforts to include the study of sea ice dynamics, leveraging radar datasets to model sea ice concentration and drift in the Arctic. This work provided valuable insights into regional variations in sea ice thickness and movement patterns, critical for understanding polar climate changes.
  • Integrated satellite observations and regional climate models to validate and refine predictions, contributing to more accurate sea ice monitoring tools.

5.     Algorithm Comparison and Open-Source Contributions

  • Conducted comprehensive evaluations of state-of-the-art algorithms for ice surface and bed tracking in 2D and 3D radar imagery. Results were integrated into the open-source CReSIS software toolbox, benefiting the broader research community.
  • Developed user-friendly interfaces for neural network frameworks to facilitate accessibility and testing of algorithms.

Broader Impacts
The project's broader impacts include its contribution to understanding global climate systems and fostering educational opportunities. Outcomes of this research enhance predictive models of sea-level rise by improving the resolution and accuracy of ice sheet monitoring tools. Notable impacts include:

  • Climate Modeling: The automated detection of ice layers and surface features facilitates improved climate models by providing accurate datasets and tools for analyzing ice dynamics. These insights are vital for predicting future changes in sea levels and global weather patterns.
  • Educational and Professional Development:
    • The project provided research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, with particular emphasis on supporting underrepresented minorities in STEM. Students engaged in developing algorithms, testing models, and conducting simulations, gaining hands-on experience with advanced computational techniques.
    • Undergraduate students contributed to generative model tools and deep learning models.
    • Graduate theses focused on novel machine learning algorithm development and physics-informed machine learning techniques.
    • The project supported two PhD theses, two postdoctoral researchers, and several undergraduate and graduate projects. Researchers involved in the project secured internships and full-time positions at NASA, Microsoft, Amazon, DOE national labs, and academic institutions.
    • PhD students working on this project won best paper awards at major machine learning and climate change conferences.
  • Community Engagement and Dissemination:
    • Hosted workshops to discuss challenges in applying machine learning to remote sensing.
    • Collaborated with NASA, academic institutions, and private organizations like Amazon to develop accessible tools for researchers.

Key Products and Publications

1.     Software and Tools 

  • Contributions to the open-source CReSIS toolbox, including new neural network interfaces and improved internal layer trackers.
  • Development of a dashboard for radar-based layer detection, enabling wider accessibility for glaciological studies.
  • Production of AI-ready real and synthetic datasets for radar image training, augmenting real-world data and improving algorithm robustness.
  • Development of several tools for tracking internal layers of ice sheets, predicting snow accumulation thickness, and modeling spatiotemporal ice patterns.

2.     Publications and Presentations

  • This project resulted in more than 30 peer-reviewed journal and conference publications.
  • Research findings were presented at over 50 conferences, invited talks, and technical meetings.

By pioneering machine learning applications in radar data analysis, this project advanced understanding of ice sheet dynamics, climate modeling, and sea-level rise. Its open-source contributions, educational outreach, and collaborations ensure lasting benefits for scientific research and climate awareness.
